title: LLM-APTDS: A High-Precision Advanced Persistent Threat Detection System for Imbalanced Data Based on Large Language Models with Strong Interpretabilit
data:
L Yang, A Ye, Y Liu, W Lu, C Huang- Future Generation Computer Systems, 2025
Advanced persistent threats (APTs) pose a significant challenge to global 
cybersecurity, causing substantial economic losses. Existing detection methods often 
rely on expert-defined rules to map anomalous events to APT tactics. Still, they are 
highly dependent on prior knowledge, making them unsuitable for dynamic and 
complex attack scenarios. This results in insufficient fine-grained activity identification 
and attack provenance capabilities. This study proposes LLM-APTDS, an APT

title: Empirical evaluation of simulation-based fuzz testing for autonomous driving systems
data:
H Yang, Y Zhou, T Chen- Empirical Software Engineering, 2026
Autonomous driving systems (ADS) are an emerging technology with promising 
potential in areas such as intelligent cities and transportation. Testing ADS is of 
paramount importance before their deployment in real-world vehicles, where 
simulation-based testing provides a cost-effective way to assess the performance of 
ADS. Several simulation-based fuzz testing tools have been developed, but there 
lacks a systematic empirical study to evaluate and compare their performance. To
Cites: BLEEM: Packet Sequence Oriented Fuzzing for Protocol
author: Abhik Roychoudhury

title: Investigating the efficacy of fuzz testing
data:
PTJ Grz - 2025
This thesis explores three aspects of fuzzer efficacy. First, we adapt mutation analysis 
for fuzzer benchmarking. Traditional mutation analysis is computationally prohibitive 
for fuzzers, we contribute optimizations enabling practical benchmarking. We 
validate this approach through an initial evaluation and a fuzzer competition. 
Second, we compare fuzzers and static analysis tools. Measuring bugs detected and 
effort required to act on reported bugs. Results show minimal overlap, justifying using
Cites: Fuzzing: Challenges and Reflections
author: Abhik Roychoudhury
ref: 6 new citations to articles by Abhik Roychoudhury

title: SGAFuzzer: Stateful GraphQL API Fuzzing
data:
J Sun, X Song, X Liu, S Guo, C Hu - 2025
GraphQL has become increasingly popular in modern web development due to its 
flexibility and efficiency in data retrieval. However, existing fuzzing techniques for 
GraphQL APIs face challenges in handling dependencies between operations, 
which limits their ability to generate effective test cases and detect deep software 
bugs. This paper proposes SGAFuzzer, an automated stateful fuzzing framework 
designed to enhance the testing of GraphQL APIs. Specifically, SGAFuzzer performs
Cites: Stateful Greybox Fuzzing

data:
A Ghosh, L Malva, A Gotovos, D Hooshyar, A Singla- arXiv preprint arXiv:2512.11735, 2025

However, the relative impact of these methods during the learning and post-learning 
phases remains unclear. In this work, we present a large-scale study comparing the

during learning and on novel tasks post-learning. Specifically, we compare three

Cites: Synthesizing Tasks for Block-based Programming

title: How Low Can You Go? The Data-Light SE Challenge
data:
KK Ganguly, T Menzies- arXiv preprint arXiv:2512.13524, 2025
Much of software engineering (SE) research assumes that progress depends on 
massive datasets and CPU-intensive optimizers. Yet has this assumption been 
rigorously tested? The counter-evidence presented in this paper suggests otherwise: 
across dozens of optimization problems from recent SE literature, including software 
configuration and performance tuning, cloud and systems optimization, project and 
process-level decision modeling, behavioral analytics, financial risk modeling
